title: How to Make Rajma

steps.headline: Rinse the rajma until the water runs clear.
steps.description: Place 1 cup (200 g) of dried rajma into a strainer or colander. Rinse the beans under cool, running water until the water runs clear. Rajma is the same thing as red kidney beans. Sift the beans with your fingers while you rinse them to ensure that they rinse evenly.

steps.headline: Soak the rajma in water for at least 4 to 6 hours.
steps.description: Place the rinsed rajma into a pot, then cover them with several inches/centimeters of water. Cover the pot with a loose-fitting lid, then set it aside for at least 4 to 6 hours. It would be even better if you allowed them to soak overnight, about 8 to 9 hours. Plan on using about 4 cups (0.95 L) of water. Soaking the beans is very important because it will help them cook faster.

steps.headline: Drain the rajma and discard the water.
steps.description: Pour the beans through a strainer or colander over a sink. If you want to, you can rinse the beans with fresh water to help remove any starches. Don't keep the soaking water, however, or it will turn the dish too gassy.

steps.headline: Place the rajma, water, salt, and turmeric into a pressure cooker.
steps.description: Fill a pressure cooker with 4 cups (0.95 L) of water. Add the rinsed and drained beans, some salt, and about 1/4 teaspoon of turmeric powder. If you like things spicy, add a green chili pepper.

steps.headline: Cook the beans over high heat for about 15 to 20 minutes.
steps.description: The beans are ready when they are soft; some may even be split open. Keep in mind, however, that each pressure cooker is a little different. Yours may finish cooking the beans faster, or it may need a little more time. Start preparing the masala while you wait for the rajma to cook. If you wish to serve the beans with a different type of sauce or curry, then get started on that instead. For Indian pressure cookers, this will take about 3 or 4 whistles.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion in oil over medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Place 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of oil into a medium-sized pan. Place the pan on the stove, then turn the heat up to medium. Once the oil starts to form bubbles, add 2 medium-sized, finely-chopped onions. Sauté the onions until they turn translucent. You can use any type of cooking oil you want. For extra flavor, add a dash of salt. Stir the onions often with a wooden spatula so that they don't burn. Don't let them turn golden-brown just yet! If you prefer a smoother texture, use 1/2 cup (115 g) of onion paste instead. Sauté it in 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of oil until it turns light brown.

steps.headline: Add the ginger and garlic and sauté the mixture for 3 to 4 minutes.
steps.description: Add 1 teaspoon of minced ginger and 1 teaspoon of minced garlic. Give the mixture a stir with your wooden spatula, then sauté it for about 3 to 4 minutes, or until the onion starts to turn golden-brown. Stir the onion, ginger, and garlic often while you sauté them. If you want a smoother texture, use 1½ tablespoons of ginger-garlic paste instead.

steps.headline: Pour in the tomato puree and cook the sauce, covered, for 6 to 7 minutes.
steps.description: Add 2 cups (450 g) of tomato puree into the pan. Stir it with the wooden spatula, then cover it with a lid and let it cook for about 6 to 7 minutes. It's ready once the oil bubbles up to the top of the tomato puree. Remember to stir your mixture often so that it doesn't stick to the pan. If you are using freshly-made tomato puree, cook it for 10 to 12 minutes instead to ensure that the tomatoes cook all the way through.

steps.headline: Stir in the coriander, masala, and water, and cook for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Add 1 teaspoon of dried coriander, 1 teaspoon of chaat masala, and 1 teaspoon of garam masala. Stir in ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of water. Allow the masala to cook for about 2 minutes. The water will help the spices mix into the tomato puree. It will also keep it from getting burnt. If the masala is very thick, use ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of water instead. For extra flavor, use the cooking water from the beans in the pressure cooker. You can also use fresh water.

steps.headline: Wait for the pressure on the pressure cooker to drop, then open it.
steps.description: This is known as a "natural release." You don't have to open the valve of do anything; just wait 5 to 30 minutes for the pressure to drop. Not all pressure cookers can release pressure naturally. For example, some cookers require you to open a valve. Check the instructions that came with your cooker.

steps.headline: Add the rajma to the masala, give it a stir, then return it to a boil.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon to take the beans out of the pressure cooker and transfer them to the masala. You will have to make several trips in order to transfer all of the beans.

steps.headline: Allow the rajma and masala to cook for about 10 minutes, uncovered.
steps.description: Everything should be fully-cooked at this point, so this is only to allow the masala to thicken. The longer you cook the masala, the thicker it will become. Start with 10 minutes, then cook the masala longer, if desired. For a thicker masala, cook it for 20 minutes. You can cook the masala a little longer than that for an even thicker texture.

steps.headline: Stir in 2 to 3 tablespoons (30 to 45 mL) of cream for a richer flavor.
steps.description: This is completely optional and will give you something similar to what’s served in restaurants. Be sure to stir it in well, so that the color and texture of the masala is consistent; there should be no streaks or swirls.

steps.headline: Serve the rajma masala while it is still hot.
steps.description: It tastes delicious with steamed basmati rice. You can also garnish it with some chopped coriander. Plan on using about 2 to 3 tablespoons (5 to 7.5 g) of chopped coriander and 2 to 3 cups (500 to 750 g) of steamed rice. Not a fan of rice? Eat it as a stew or serve it with naan. A slice of rustic bread would also taste delicious! Put any leftover rajma into a covered container and store it in the fridge for up to 3 or 5 days.
